content.description:
Trundle up a loose ledge system to a short RF dihedral. Stem your way up until you grab a right sidepull pinch. Hold right sidepull pinches all the way to the chains. Don't let go. Tada. Now you've sent Atlantis.

Walk a really long time. This route is under the huge roofs up at the right side of the wall.  This is one of the shorter routes, and starts in a shallow RF dihedral, following a wet-looking crack system. There is a plaque. Otherwise... good luck. There are a lot of routes here and they all look the same.
Bolts. Seems to have draws hanging usually. Best clipped from right sidepull pinches.

Start up a left trending ramp for three bolts, then head up and right into a corner with some stemming, shoulder scuffing, and a fingery seam. Reach a broken ledge, then continue up the blocky corner system to an anchor on the right face.

Start under a large right-facing corner to the right of a blocky roof.
11 bolts to an anchor with a single chain.

Steeper climbing leads to a techy face. Climbing above the chains, which are visible from the ground, is 5.13a.

Scramble onto ledge on the right side of Saddle Up Wall. This route is near the middle of the ledge, just right of Sunny Days.
6 bolts to chains

Two easy bolts of climbing gains you a tenuous stance. From here, high clip the chain-draw and then pull on the only bad holds on the route. 

Cruise to the roof, clip overhead and pull through. After this, the vast majority of the climb is cruiser, with the exception of a single move on a crimp (possibly the crux?). Just before the corner at the top there is a fairly marginal rock band. If you don't use the approved beta, it is likely you'll pull something off. 

Walk the corner to the top - there is a move or two here!

*Route is right around 30 m, ideally climb it on a rope that is longer than 60 m. 



Rightmost bolt line on the ledge at the left side of the wall. Look for the chain draw, and the left slanting, fin styled roof. 

13 bolts, fixed anchor with biners

A V10 crux off the deck leads into more hard climbing. Evan has been working on this for a couple years now and I'm amazed he pulled it off! Congrats! 
  
  instagram.com/p/BUYFx01g7nL… 
  
 From Sendage: 
  
 "Can't believe it's done!!! What an incredible journey! After chasing this grade for years I knew the only way I could get it done was to find and bolt one at home in The Bow Valley, Canada. It took many trips to Europe to try various routes of this grade and understand what I was looking for. At last I was able to find a completely independent line at the perfect difficulty at a cliff I already frequented anyway! I started bolting this route 16 months ago last April and tried to get on it as much as possible since then, pretty much 12 out of the last 16 month it's been climbable. In the cold, in the hot, wet, whatever. Today was incredible. Amazing conditions, I felt tired on the warmup so I didn't really think I had a shot, but maybe that took some of the pressure off. I passed my highpoint and then I didn't fall off the final move like I thought I would. STOKED!! About the grade: I reckon it's a 15m 9a to a mediocre rest followed by 30m of pumpy 8c climbing ending in a huge roof. It feels on par with the few 9a+s I've tried in Europe and definitely harder than any 9a I've been on so I'm going with 9a+. This is my first of the grade and a lifetime goal for sure."

Sport

A nice boulder problem above the first break leads to a reclined, no-hands back rest. Pull over the lip and cruise a relatively chill crack to the chains. 



Starts just right of and below the ledge towards the left end of the wall. Look for the distinctive, ~hand sized crack/right facing corner with bolts. 

8 bolts, chains with biners

75 m of rope gets you to the ground, 70 m does not. 

Start up a shallow, right facing corner sort of feature to gain a good hand ledge/clipping stance for bolt 3 (back-clean bolt 1). Pull onto the ledge and boulder up to the break, passing either left or right of the bolt line. 

Take your awkward rest in the corner/roof and prepare yourself for a handful of intro moves leading into a hard compression to Gaston boulder. A handful of exit moves gets you to the large horizontal weakness where you can effectively fully recover. All that's left is 20 m of apocalyptically pumpy hero climbing to the chains!



~5 m right of an ~8 m tall fin/right-facing acute corner (Tosinator) and immediately left of Aquarius (plaque at bottom). Towards the right side of the wall, left of the biggest low roof. 

23 bolts (21 crag draws and a perma), anchor with biners.

Follow a large flake feature that arcs left and then cruise up. This involves starting on the right side, in a right facing corner (3 bolts, back clean as you go, move your belayer after you have pulled around the corner to the left),and then bucket slamming to the midway anchor. Do not clip the anchor...or if you do, put a draw on the chain to extend it. Do this from THE best hold in the Bow Valley. 

Step to the right and solve a simple boulder problem using a pair of side-pulls and finishing at the next bolt on buckets. A couple more moves get you out of trouble to a good rest. 20 m of cruiser climbing leads you to the chains (lots of big holds, a bit of beta, and opportunities for pump management). 

Bring at least one draw (for the crux bolt, not counting the first 3 bolts), lower twice.



Look for the giant flake feature with neon green, long perma's. Follow the bolt line with these perma's all the way to the top. 

19 bolts (15 permas), 2 bolt anchor with biners.

Powerful resistance climbing right off the ground. The holds are huge, but none of them face up. Try to recover at the mid-height rest before attempting the thinner, more strenuous section into the fin. Take the fin to the chains! More style points awarded for laybacking, but it is possible to chimney as well, either way, the fin is too big to fall off of. 

Stick clip, 2 if you can! Helps to dab on the 14b (Dime Piece) to the right to start. 



Just left of the second bench (the one that looks out towards Canmore). Look for the bolt line that leads into the telltale fin feature starting 15 m off the deck or so. Starts off the choss stack. 

13 bolts, fixed anchor with biners.

Really just 5.10 climbing to two boulders separated by a jug so big it puts the Altius bathtub rail to shame. Nobody would blow it after that. Only have to clip every second bolt.


Bolts

Start on the right edge of the giant flake in a right facing corner. Clip and back clean the first 3 bolts, stepping left onto the face of the flake with permas. Break off the permas to go straight up on the crack; it is disappointingly strenuous to gain the mid-way anchor. Long draw both of the bolts on this lower section. 

At the anchor (skip it, do not clip it), traverse hard right ~2 m to a good rest and a clip at your thigh. Cross the obvious break in the wall and gain the headwall with a big, but not so hard move. A strenuous clip leads to a thin boulder, the last move of which may result in your feet helicoptering off the wall. Victory climbing to the chains - only clip the long draws. Bring a draw for the second last bolt. 



Toward the right of the wall, look for the giant flake and the neon green perma-draws. This line goes straight up after the second green perma-draw. 

19 bolts (12 permas), rap rings.

Make a few steep moves on good jugs and trend left through fractured rock to lower-angle rock above.

Scramble up on a ledge on the left side of Saddle Up Wall. This route is located near the middle of the ledge just left of a small slot cave.
6 bolt to chains

Follow left-trending blocky terrain for 40 feet, then head up and slightly right through the thinner crux section.

Right of a cave used to stash gear and left of blocky corner. There is a belay anchor bolt on the right side of the base of the route with a cut portion of rope at the time of this writing.
7 bolts to chain anchor.

climbs.name: Zoophycus
climbs.fa: Ross Suchy, Matt Pieterson, Simon Meis, 2005

content.description:
Start up a blocky pillar feature to a pedestal  where you clip your first bolt. Cruise through easy terrain (a very loosely defined open book feature with a sort of crack) on good holds to a roof. Pass it to the right, before stepping back to the left to set up for a short and slightly awkward boulder. 

Victory climbing to the chains - step right and head up on a mix of pockets, buckets, finger buckets, side pulls and whatever you call the pinchy pinch thing just before the top. The holds can be tricky to see, the rock is quite bright/white. 

There is a good stance at the anchor to rest if you're eyeing up the extension - 10 more meters and 4 more bolts (look up/right). 

QD note - before the first roof there is a good rest. Step up and clip over head, return to the rest and back clean the lower draw to reduce drag. Consider extending the draw before this one as well (in the vicinity of bolt 4). 



From the bench with a back rest, walk climbers left along the cliff. Look for the ~3 m tall pillar with a bolt standing height above its top. 

16 bolts, fixed anchor with biners.
The third wall, has some really hard lines. Enjoy hiking up for days to project these monster lines. Get your endurance up!
